chargeHist.descr: Use a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime
Use a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime

result.execSummary:
On one or more charges, the deferred prosecution or sentencing agreement(s) on this case were fulfilled, and the charge(s) were dismissed.

The defendant Todd H. Jelinski was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Child Enticement-Sexual Contact, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.07(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

charges.descr: Use a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime

supervisions.notes:
Court authorizes transfer of probation to Sawyer County. 
Probation with possibility of early release if deemed appropriate by agent.

miscConds.notes: FTE for at least 30 hours per week or if not, perform 5 hours of community service per week unless physically impossible.

No contact with children under the age of 18 except as allowed by agent.  

No work or volunteer with children under the age of 18.

Sex offender registration.  Comply with sex offender rules of probation. 

DNA sample. 

Assessment/counseling as deemed appropriate by the department. 

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been faxed to the probation office.

timeConds.notes: IMPOSED AND STAYED for rule violations

records.addlTxt: AMENDED
w/Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief
DEOJ Agreement on Count 1
from Atty Lawson to Judge Huber re: sentencing

Clerk Marisa.
Case Called: 11:02 am 
State appears by DDA Theresa Wetzsteon; Def appears in person with Atty Richard Lawson.  
Plea Quest/Waiver of Rights filed. 
State moves to file amended information. COURT grants. 

PLEA: 
Ct. 1 (Use a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime)>>GUILTY. 
Ct. 2 (Child Enticement)>>GUILTY. 

COURT advises def of rights (including constitutional rights) & penalties & ques def to understanding.  
COURT finds plea & waiver of rights freely & vol made, a factual basis, def guilty on Ct. 2, and defers entry of judgment on Ct. 1. 
Argument re: conditional jail time. Def makes statement. 

COURT ORDERS: On Ct. 1>>DEOJ for 6 years with conditions as outlined in written agreement. 
                           : On Ct. 2>>SWH for 6 years probation with possibility of early release if deemed appropriate by agent - CONDITIONS: 120 days MCJ imposed and STAYED for rule violations; assessment/counseling as deemed appropriate by the dept; fulltime employment for at least 30 hours per week or if not, perform 5 hours community service per week unless physically impossible; no contact with children under the age of 18 except as allowed by agent; sex offender registration; No work or volunteer with children under the age of 18; comply with sex offender rules of probation; DNA sample and surcharge; payment of court costs. 
COURT finds def is entitled to 4 days jail credit if revoked. 
COURT authorizes transfer of probation to Sawyer County. 
Review of DEOJ set for February 11, 2021 at 1:10 pm with Br. 2 JA.

Status conference on September 15, 2014 at 02:30 pm.
MODIFIED

MODIFIED -Allow defendant to have supervised contact with nieces and nephews by adults at least 25 years of age and Defendant may have incidental contact in public places. Allow defendant to have contact with P.K. as long as it is supervised and the parents of P.K. are to be notified. Remainder of the bond will stay the same regarding no contact with minors under 18 years of age unless at work and then no unsupervised contact. Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney. No computers unless for work and to be monitored.
